item.description:
Press Start Pocket is a 2 player game deck of 56 cards.

Each deck (Series 1, Series 2, Series 3) is a stand-alone 2 player game. Two decks can be combined for a 3-4 player game, and 3 decks can be combined for a 5-6 player game. Combining decks also gives expanded capabilities for warriors.


Battle to win control of the pixel world.

Players start with a video game warrior and battle their opponent to take control of the video game universe.

There is no hiding, to win you have to battle.

Overview:

Both players get 7 cards and the rest of the cards are placed in 2 piles face down in the middle of the table.

Pile 1 is a warrior card pile

Pile 2 is an action card pile

The first player draws and action card then either attacks, plays a gather card to earn points toward another warrior or discards.

During a battle the players follow the attacks and counters rule according to the reference card.

To win a player must win 3 battles or earn 4 soldiers all alive at once.

Integrates with:


 Press Start Pocket: Series 1 
 Press Start Pocket: Series 2

Experience the thrill and excitement of horse racing with the new Quarter Horse Racing Game! Comes with the board, deck of cards, game pieces, a pair of dice, and instructions. Cheer on your favorite horses as each roll gets them one step closer to the finish line. Get there first and the jackpot is yours!

Plotypus is a collaborative storytelling card game; it enables any group to tell an epic story with a riveting plot. Players draw setting and character cards for inspiration and narrate the story through eight pivotal chapters.

During the Story phase, players advance the plot a few sentences before rotating narrator. The Storybook cards help focus the plot.

At the start of the game, the hero is stuck in their normal routine. As the story continues, the players explore the hero's adventure and clash with the villain. The game ends when players have completed the storybook deck and described the hero in their new routine, having triumphed over their antagonist.

This appears to be a version of Kalah by William Julius Champion Jr. A seed sowing game with 6 pits in a circle. Play involves scooping up pebbles from a pit and sowing the pebbles, one at a time, into the other pits.

Part of the Mancala Family.

Similar to Snap, but instead of matching a single card, players are trying to create "11" from the sum of two or more upturned cards. When players see it, they have to shout out "Legs".

The illustrations feature children playing and super-imposed with the number of the card.

This is the final field exam of your bomb disposal training course. The instructor has rigged three training bombs for you and your team to defuse, but little do you know that there is no way to actually defuse them! The bombs will explode eventually, and if you want to graduate at the top of the class then you’ll want to cut high-value wires without triggering the explosives! Grab your wire cutters and steady that shaky hand, because it’s going to be an explosive night!

In Bomb Squad Academy there are four decks of cards representing the four “wires” of the bomb, and a trigger track next to each deck. Every round, each player secretly decides (then simultaneously reveals) the wire that they will cut this round (or perhaps they’ll chicken out, or even call “Wait!” preventing a wire from being cut). After actions are revealed, the chosen wires are “cut” by flipping cards from those decks. When a card is flipped, its value dictates how far the trigger moves down the trigger track and how many points are earned; cutting wires alone is worth a lot more than cutting the same wire as other players. Push the triggers too far and the bomb will explode! Whoever causes the bomb to explode loses points. Players earn useful Tools during the game that they can use to break the rules. Get through three gruelling bombs with the cleverest cuts to finish your final exam with the most points!

item.description:
A roll and move game with numbered spaces by Otto Maier Verlag. Players start at the first space and must follow the numbered spaces in towards the center space. First one to reach the end space is the winner.

The company published a different game by the same name a few decades later: Reise durch die Schweiz

The Story

Blend it Like Becca—a small-town smoothie shop sensation!

It’s been a slow night, and Becca the shop owner, her young son Kevin and the Master Mixers -- including you! -- have started closing up shop. One minute before close, the door swings open. Outside, you see parked school buses and a line of people all the way to the street corner! The high school girl’s volleyball tournament has just gotten out, and everyone is craving a smoothie for the ride home. Becca cuts a deal: whoever blends the most smoothies tonight gets free smoothies for a month!

The Blend Off has begun, and only one can win. There’s just one problem: Kevin. Skittish at best on normal days, he flies into a frenzy, grabbing fruit for you from the fridge at random. Grab the fruit, complete the Orders, and blend your way to victory!

				
					Overview

Blend Off! is a game of skill and speed for two to four players from designer Scot Eaton. Master Mixers roll the die (Kevin) to collect fruit to fill Orders from the deck (Becca). When a Master Mixer's fruit matches the Order, they can blend the ingredients and claim the Order for gold stars. There are no turns; everyone plays at the same time in a race for the finish. The winner is the player with the most gold stars at the end of the game.

				
					Gameplay

The actions the player may take at any time are: Collect, Blend, Dump, and Blunder.

Collect - Roll your die to send Kevin to the fridge for fruit. You may take one of the fruit from the table and put it on one of your Blenders. You don’t have to take the fruit; you may reroll the dice until Kevin brings you what you want.

Dump - You may dump the fruit out of one of your Blenders. Because the fruit is already mixed together, you may not dump just one or two ingredients; you must dump the whole Blender. You may, however, choose to dump one Blender into another, combining ingredients.

Blend - When the fruit in one of your Blenders matches the recipe on one of the faceup Orders, shout out “Blend!”

Blunder - If you catch another player make a mistake like calling “Blend!” with wrong or extra ingredients in their Blender, shout “Blunder!” They must correct their mistake by dumping their Blender and, returning the Order card for their botched recipe to Becca’s deck.

Hexagonal Wars is a flexible strategy game for 2 to 4 players. Despite being easy to learn, it is a complex game. You have to think over each of your moves carefully. Each player has to plan and conform to every situation and control a team that they assembled, while their goal is to kill the enemy forces. One big advantage of the game is that every match is different, because the war maps, units, and cards all guarantee a variety of gameplay for unlimited replayability!

item.description:
Tricks and Deserts is a trick taking game where players play as cunning human authorities trying to obtain controls of magical species with powerful abilities.

Each turn, players will be playing 1 specie card either face up or face down. The player that played the strongest card (usually the card with the highest number) takes all face up cards. Playing cards face down is called "passing," and these cards are abandoned to the desert. The play continues until all cards are played from player's hands.

The face-up cards you take scores points, but the abandoned cards will affect your scoring, sometimes positively, and sometime negatively. You must choose wisely when to play and when to pass.

A travel edition of Suomirokkia trivia with fewer components and questions.

A trivia game with 200 questions about Finnish rock music from 1970-2009.

In The Staufer Dynasty, the players are nobles in the 12th century, accompanying Henry VI on his tour of the areas of Europe brought under control by the Staufer family, an area that included much of modern-day Germany, from the Baltic Sea in the north to Sicily in the south. You're eager to improve your own lot in the land by placing envoys and nobles in positions of power in the six regions represented in this game.

The game lasts five rounds with each player having three actions per round. Players take actions in order of their family members on the action board from top to bottom; on a turn you either take a supply action (moving to one side of the action board) or a move/deploy action (moving to the other side).

For a supply action, you pick one of the spaces on the supply table, move the indicated number of envoys and nobles from the province to your personal court, then claim any chests underneath that space. The treasure chests come in different colors, with each color having a different function in the game: the brown treasure chests score points based on how many you collect, the orange ones provide immediate points or figures, the blue ones provide a one-shot bonus, and the purple ones let you collect one of the privilege cards on display. The privilege cards often modify other actions or give you a bonus for doing a particular thing.

For a move/deploy action, you decide which office seat you want to occupy in a particular region. If this seat isn't in the region where the king is located, you need to spend one envoy as you move clockwise away from the king, placing each envoy in the top part of those regions, until you reach the region that you want to occupy. You then pay the cost of the office seat, placing one figure — possibly a noble if the seat demands it — in that seat and all the other figures in clockwise order, one per region. When you occupy a seat, you claim the chest underneath it.

After everyone has finished their actions, you score for the round — but you score only in the region indicated in the current row of scoring tiles (Aachen, Nijmegen, Palermo, etc.) and the region that best meets the condition laid out in a separate part of the current row of scoring tiles (fewest chests, most occupants, where the king is located, etc.) If these two regions turn out to be the same one, you score that region only once. Players score points for having the most office seats in a region (or the second- or thirdmost most office seats) based on the point tile placed in the region at the start of the game. Each region also has a printed bonus that players receive, such as bonus chests or additional envoys.

To end the round, you remove all of the office occupants of the region that scored, add new chests under each office seat in those scoring regions and each space on the supply table, then sweep the king clockwise 1-3 regions. As the king moves, he returns all of the envoys that he encounters in the regions that he enters to their owners. After five rounds, players score for their treasure chests as well as for how well they completed their secret job cards, and the player with the most points wins.

item.description:
Evolutio! is a cooperative board game for 2-5 persons aged 10+. It aims to develop cooperation skills, understanding and responsibled decision making. Using European funds, players develop various Polish regions. They decide which accumulated raw materials to transfer, and negotiate with each other to determine which sectors require support. At the same time, they need to work together to deal with the game events.

Successful investment in six economic areas (transport, environment, energy, culture, science and health) supported by the Programme 'Infrastructure and Environment', result in changes throughout the country and affect the level of citizen satisfaction. The key to success is the ability for concerted action, strategic planning and making difficult decisions.

Race around Monstro City collecting items from the shops and answering questions along the way. Once your collection is complete be the first to the centre of the board to answer the ultimate Moshi question and claim the Golden Iggy Trophy.

A simple roll and move quiz game.

This entry is for the 2-6 player edition with 84 cards. The entry for the 2-4 player edition with 55 cards is here.


In this fast-paced card game based on Scrabble, each player is dealt a hand of two-sided cards: each one has a different letter on each side, and a pair of letters in the corners that note which letters are on each face. Players create a four-letter word to start the game, then replace one letter at a time with cards from their hands. The first player to get rid of all their cards wins.

In this strategic family game, you're a Sifaka in the deserts of Madagascar. In addition to sunbathing, you try to collect as many mangoes as possible, but take because some mangoes are more valuable than others. Only having the most points leads to victory.

Sifaka is a tactical card game for up to four players, all of whom try to find the most valuable mangoes. By playing a card, the player activates his Sifaka, allowing him traveling through the desert. The movement speed and direction is determined by covering cards. If a player wants to move five fields, they must cover five palms; to change the direction, they need to cover an arrow. If you see a mango symbol mapped on the card, a corresponding mango token will be placed on it immediately. If a player stops their Sifaka on a field with a mango, they collect it immediately.

Ones all the cards have been played, the game ends, and whoever has the most points on his mangoes wins.

item.description:
Release! is a light card game about software and the people who make it. The game is simple: manage cooperation and competition with other players across five releases to score the most points. Each round of Release! is played the same way, but the scoring rules change as you reveal new tools and methods. Your team needs to continuously respond to these strategic shifts in order to produce the best release possible.

Release's core mechanics are modeled after classic trick trump games. Rounds, or releases, are played by each player contributing a card to a trick, generally the highest card thrown takes the trick. This continues until the players are out of cards, at which point in time they score the release.

Scoring rules are where it gets tricky. Every release the players will reveal a new scoring methodology. These scoring rules award or subtract points for taking; various combinations of cards, lump sums of suits, or a specific number of tricks. This means that some rounds you want may want to lose as many tricks as possible, win as many as possible, or fish for specific cards.

The face cards lend further complexity, these cards all have special bonus powers that do things like: affect their rank, steal previously won cards, award instant points, and much more.

The game itself is themed to evoke certain trends of software development. Themeing elements include naming conventions, fun copy, and the face cards are all modeled after famous 'faces' of the development community.

item.description:
Are you the best rapper in your neighbourhood?

Challenge your friends and family to see who is the lyrical master, and who couldn't rap their way out of a cardboard box.

How to play

Pick up a "rap card" and a "star card" to determine the style of your performance. Roll the dice to select the tune on the beat box, and performs your freestyle rap. Get paid for each successfully completed rap, and the first to $1000 wins the game.

A press-your-luck card game of sci-fi goodness.

You are the captain of a salvage ship. It isn't glamorous but it is profitable. The salvage of a lifetime just drifted into nearby space. Unfortunately, you're not the only salvage crew to respond. Since you all arrive at the derelict together, interstellar salvage laws apply. Within the ship are dangers and rewards alike, just waiting for you.

In this fast-paced game of risk-taking and decision-making, you and up to four additional players try to claim the most salvage from the derelict ship before its failing engines finally explode. You'll go room to room gathering up salvage and avoiding deadly hazards. Will you get out of the derelict and tuck away your acquired salvage, or press your luck against the growing threat of the deadly hazards?

This game can be played in under 30 minutes and is simple enough to be grasped by young players. Older players, however, will enjoy it even more as they weigh the odds and make their decisions.

Each player is a faction that has an immunity, and the push your luck aspect comes from flipping the top card of the deck. You can get salvage points that are evenly distributed among the players left on the ship and the left over goes to a kitty. You can also flip over a hazard, which only kills you the second time a hazard of the same type is revealed. Before you flip the next card, you have a tile that says, stay, or to back to ship. If you go back to ship, you keep the points that you have gathered and take the kitty points. If you stay, you keep going until everyone dies or leaves for their ship. There are five stages of the game. Each stage you also shuffle an artifact and a black hazard which no one is immune to into the deck. Each faction also has an artifact that will score them 20 points, whereas if you don't get your special artifact, it is only 10 points. At the end of the five stages, whoever has the most points wins.

Tu dors au gaz, released as Qui dort dîne in Europe, is a party game to play during a meal.

To play, three cards — two blue and one red — are visible to all players. One player takes the role of the master, and when the master does the action named on one of the cards, if the card is blue the first player to do the reaction named on the card wins one point and becomes the new master; if the card is red, the last player to do the reaction loses one point and names another player as the new master. If the master does the action of a blue card three times without any reaction, he wins this card (one point). The first player to earn three points wins the game and doesn't have to do the dishes.

Demonslayer: The Siege of Mt. Kunlun is what is called a 'deck-building game,' for up to four players. The game is based on the story “Warriors of Magic Mountain.” Each player takes control of one Sect of the Kunlun Immortals, and they must compete with each other in defeating the dread forces of the Heart-Eaters. By defeating the Heart-Eaters, each player accumulates Cultivation. At the end of the game, once all the Heart-Eaters are defeated, the player with the most Cultivation is the winner.

Every turn, players play a “hand” of cards, building up the player’s “ready deck” and attacking the demon enemies. In each turn, players can "obtain" a card once, and attack once. Players can obtain spells as well as obtain "meditation" cards which are used to obtain more, stronger cards. Players may also "obtain" Immortal warriors from their Immortal Roster area; Immortals are the foot-soldiers in the war against the Heart-Eaters.

Each turn of the game is strategically important; one wrongly played hand can mean the difference between first and last place.

There are four Sects of Immortals in Demonslayer, and each plays differently from each other. The Kunlun Sect excels at bringing high-powered Immortal warriors out quickly, each building on the other’s strength. The Qicheng sect is good at calling on reserve Immortals to join the battle. The Kongtong Sect is proficient at Alchemy; creating powerful artifacts which help the Sect in it’s battle’s against the Heart Eaters. The noble Wuyi Sect Immortal Warriors sacrifice themselves for devastating combo attacks. Every sect also has 1 Sect Leader Immortal, who provides special powers which serve to define how the sect plays.

The enemy of the game are the “Heart-Eaters;” demonic warriors who have attained immortality by reveling in lustful destruction and excess. Many of the heart eaters have spiritual parasites – called “Miasma” which infect the players after slaying. However, players also sometimes attack “Treasure Beasts” which can grant players special abilities once they are won.

In one "wave" of Demonslayer, there are 8 Heart Eaters and one "Overlord;" a leader of that wave of Heart-Eaters. Demonslayer: Siege of Mt. Kunlun is not, strictly speaking, a game of inter-player competition. Players compete with each other to have the honor of being the most successful at protecting the heavens and Earth from the demon hoards. Yet, players are are essentially cooperating to defeat the enemy.

This English-language version of the game already incorporates one expansion, called The Alchemist's Fortune. In time, we will release new expansions for you to enjoy, incorporating more players, more cards, more options, more strategy, and most of all – more fun.

Two simple games of (color-)dice for children 3 and up, both set in a playground setting.
In the first one, the players try to collect sandbox toys in 5 different colors, whoever has all five colors first, wins.
In the second one, the players move across color-coded steps by throwing a color dice. Ladders act as shortcuts, slides move the pieces backwards. The player who reaches the tower at the end of the steps first, wins.

Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Ulm
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Elmshorn. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.

- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Elmshorn. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.

Up through the Middle Ages, the Westphalian Hellweg, a road between Duisburg and Paderborn that's more than five thousand years old, was of great importance for trading.

In Hellweg westfalicus, players try their hand at trading, trying to buy salt, beer, and ironware at low prices, then sell them for maximum profit. If you wait too long, you might get a good purchase price, but only for what little is still left to sell. You can create trade routes with the help of coaches and thus supply distant towns. The player who owns the most money after twelve rounds wins.

Hellweg westfalicus includes the expansion module "Warehouse and Privileges" for expert players.

item.description:
Join Stevie, Carole and Lisa in the ultimate cross country course. Complete jumps and collect cards along the way, but watch you dont fail the vet check. Contains 3D moulded jumps for an authentic cross country experience. Colourful moulded horses for easy player identification.
Winner is the person to cross all jumps and then cross the finish line.

This is an early game for young children. Players start with a supply of fish, and roll dice on each turn. The dice tell whether the player should pass a fish to another player, put a fish in the food bowl, take a fish from the bowl, or do nothing for that turn. The last player with fish is the winner.

You are a Dragon. Like all respectable dragons you must find yourself a Princess and horde some treasure. There are some nearby towns just ripe for the plunder. You must strafe these villages with your dragonflame until they submit and hand over their treasures. But of course, you're not the only Dragon out there!

In DragonFlame you will take turns placing 3 cards on to the Castle cards in the center of the table. This will create piles of cards that you will get to choose from at the end of the round. The pile you choose will also determine your turn order for the next round.

Once you've taken a pile you place the cards in front of you for end game scoring. Any DragonFire cards you have acquired give you the ability to flame the villages for a area-control over these cards (more victory points).

Since sometimes you may place a card face down, this becomes a game of reading the other players and choosing the right (sometimes poisoned) piles. Do you take that pile with a lot of cards and risk the minus points or just go for the safe face up treasures?

There are several types of treasures to collect. You will only score 1 of the types of chests and the others count against you. Some treasures are just straight forward points. Some are even powerful magic items with special abilities.

item.description:
It's the bottom of the ninth inning. The game is tied. It's down to the home team to score one run to win it all. Unfortunately, the home team is staring down the league's best closer.

A dice and card game for two players, Bottom of the 9th brings all the excitement of the final three outs of a baseball game into a compact 5-20 minute game session. With variable player strengths, bluffing/deduction, and die-rolling, only the pitcher knows what's coming and the batter needs to keep his eyes peeled. Bottom of the 9th is played over the course of three outs, or four hits (for one run scored) — whichever occurs first.

Bottom of the 9th includes tons of variable player powers, myriad customizable line-ups, the possibility of two added expansion packs, and rules for advanced league and solo play to keep gamers wanting to play ball time and time again.

item.description:
2 to 6 players start the game in Hawaii with a private jet and $20 Million in cash. Players roll dice to determine movement options and attempt circumnavigate the globe on a 26 x 16 map-grid, visiting major cities in each continent.

At each city, players can purchase investments that will either grow their wealth or induce bankruptcy. They can also punish their opponents by forcing them to distant corners of the globe or by performing hostile takeovers of their investments.

The game ends when one player has visited each major city and has returned to Hawaii. Players add up their cash, investments, and other bonuses. The greatest net worth wins!

Peptide is an open-drafting card game with resource management elements. Basically, players compete to link amino acids side-by-side, forming what’s called a Peptide Chain (in biology, this process is called RNA Translation). In order to do so, players must first select from a number of available open-drafted face up cards, which in the game represent cellular organelles. Each organelle rewards players with either molecular resources or cellular actions. Final scores are based upon the types of amino acids in your Peptide Chain, and the player with the most points at the end of the game wins!

item.description:
Twistocity is a card game where players make each other perform completely 
original tongue twisters in ridiculous voices. Want to be a pirate? 
How about a robot? Or, even a Kung Fu Master!

Now, add some strategy in the form of Action cards and what do you get? 
A fun card game that will keep you laughing, AND help you become a better 
speaker, since tongue twisters are a proven method for speech improvement!

Twistocity comes with 180 full-color cards:

110 Original Tongue Twister Cards
40 Persona Cards (34 unique voices)
26 Action Cards (8 unique types)
04 Blank Cards

From the back of the box:

"The classic parlor game is now a board game!"

"From the backseat to the bar stool, follow the letter has always been a popular word game of using the last letter as the first letter in the next response."

"For example, say the category is 'states'. Player 1 says 'New York', player 2 says 'Kansas' (since New York ends in 'k'), player 3 says 'South Dakota' ... then 'Alabama', 'Arkansas' and so on. 'Follow the Letter' and have the last word to win!"

In Comparity: Films, players must place their movie cards on the table in a grid according to when they think the movie was released and how much money they think it earned: the lower-left of the grid for low-earning movies and earlier release dates, and the upper-right of the grid for high-earning movies and later release dates.

On your turn, you can place a card in the grid or check if a previous player placed their card correctly. If you check and the placement is correct, you must draw a card, but if it was placed incorrectly then the person who played it must draw.

The player who manages to get rid of all their cards first is the winner.

Magellan also publishes another version of the game, Comparity: USSR, with the same gameplay but different cards.

The official board game of the MasterChef TV Show. The players challenge to the Mystery box, Invention test, Pressure test, and have to undergo the judgment of the opponents.

Mystery box: each player has to create a dish using some ingredient cards drawn from the deck.
At the start of the challenge, they can exchange the ingredients, giving to the opponents the useless ones.
The players vote the best and the worst dish, and score points accordingly.

Invention test: each player has to create a dish using a fixed ingredient and choosing the cards by grabbing them from the middle of the table.
The players choose the ingredients simultaneously and they have to be fast to grab the best ones before the others!
The players vote and gain points like the Mystery Box.

Pressure test: the players have to guess the ingredients of a dish, looking it on a card.
The players score points according to the number of guessed ingredients.

The player with the most points will win and can wear the chef hat!

Mia and me: Rescue Centopia is a cooperative game, with Mia and me theme.
The players move their figures on the 3D board to collect the 20 Trumptus pieces.
During his turn, each player:

 moves his figure on the board, according to his energy (a value from 1 to 4).
 draws the tile on the space he lands. If it's a Trumptus piece, he can collect it. If it's an enemy, he has to lose an energy or come back on the starting space (and put the tile face down).
 draws a card and apply the effect. It could be an enemy or a bonus card (gives an energy to a player or goes to a new space)




If the players collect the 20 Trumptus pieces and go to the Panthea's castle, they win. If the cards end, they lose.

item.description:
Focus: Sarà vero? is a trivia and dexterity game.
A player reads a sentence and pushes the button to spin the wheel. After the wheel stops, all the players make an action and take simoultaneosly a disc with their suction. The action and the disc colour are indicated by the wheel.
For example:
1) the players have to stand up and turn around, or clap their hands.
2) then, if they think the sentence is true, they try to take the discs indicated by the True arrow (for example Red). Otherwise, if they think the sentence is false, they try to take the discs indicated by the False arrow (for example Blue). Because the discs of one colour aren't enough, they have to take them fast.
Who guessed the right disc, can keep it.
The player who first has 5 discs win.

Extended version: the players have to make all the actions written on the discs they won during the previous rounds.

item.description:
The party game Family Bingo requires dexterity, good memory, perceptiveness, and some basic knowledge. Players compete in eight different categories of activities, and the game includes 165 double-sided cards that tell players what to do.

A very important component of the game are 96 colorful wooden sticks in six colors; the game also includes 96 small number tokens and 16 big tokens. At the beginning of the game, each player receives a nice covering stand and personal bingo board. Players try to score a point by completing the task on the drawn card. The first player to do so covers a field on her bingo board with the number drawn at the beginning of the round. The tasks are very different, e.g., building a construction on time or after memorizing it, answering questions, guessing what another player is trying to visualize, guessing the color or number of sticks, throwing, stacking, and many, many more. Whoever creates a bingo first wins!

Cyntopia: The future is nowis a cooperative, fast-paced and action packed tabletop boardgame which takes places in a dystopic future. You'll fight huge corporations as an Edgewalker and make your living while flirting with the line. Will you fight or fall?

Cyntopia: The future is now is now takes place in a completely new cyberpunk universe. It features a cooperative gamemode for 1-7 players, a modular boardgame, over 30 miniatures and a random mission system.

The goal of the game is to fulfill your mission as Edgewalker, the mission and corporation you work against will be drawn by cards and decide the first floortile of the boardgame.

During the Edgewalk you have to fight against the guards of the corporation in a simple, yet luck and strategy based fighting system. The success of each interaction depends on the dice roll.

Four players compete in the card game Primiera to score as many points as possible, with the partnerships between players changing each round depending on who plays which card first — and sometimes it's every player for herself!

The card deck features forty cards in four suits, with each card featuring a "Primiera" value. Each round starts with four cards face-up on the table and nine cards in each player's hand. On a turn, a player must play one card to the table to try to capture one or more cards that sum to that card's value; if a player can't or doesn't want to do this, she must lay one card on the table. If you manage to clear all the cards from play, you score one point for a sweep.

The first player to lay down a Herald (which are all valued "1") determines her partner based on the direction of the arrow on that card. At the end of the round, teams combine their cards and score points, with each individual recording those points for herself. In the end, only one player can win!

Similar game play as seen in Casino and Scopa

In Journey of the Emperor players are attempting to create the best experience for the emperor during the Qingming Festival. The Emperor wishes to leave the castle and see different things on his walk along the river. The organizer that can provide him with the most desirable experience will be the winner.

Each round players will select a card representing a part of the festival and place it in a path in front of them. The full layout of cards, from castle on the left to coast on the right with the festival in between is considered a journey. Players will organize multiple journeys during a game. The goal is to figure out the best sequence to play your cards in order to score the most points and be declared the best festival organizer.

A game can take between 6 to 16 turns depending on the number of players and points are awarded for each journey depending on the Castle and Coast cards played. Each scoring card seeks out varying combinations of Dragons, Pandas, Tigers and Chows. In addition each player has hidden goals involving lanterns, animals and castle combinations.

The United States of America, 1863-69. Two railroad lines, one starting in California and the other in Iowa, set out to create a seriously divided nation’s first transcontinental railroad. In The Golden Spike, two players take on the role of a railroad magnate, building half of this famous accomplishment in transportation. It’s a race, to be sure, and the first player to reach Promontory Summit, Utah gains prestige and bonus money. However, the winner of the game is the player who makes the most profit along the way, which requires a delicate balance of planning and cunning.

Players alternately select three-card stacks from a row of them, with only one of the three cards visible. These allow the players to perform various actions, such as hiring workers and buying materials, both needed in the construction of the railroad sections they'll need to complete to get to Promontory Summit... and sometimes men and materials may be hoarded and in short supply. If an Inspector appears when turning over a face-down card, a turn ends immediately and no actions are executed. Three terrain types present a quandary for both players: faster construction or greater profits.

In any battle of Good vs. Evil, there are those who root for the noble, wholesome characters, and those who cheer on the corrupt and dishonorable. In the game of 7&7, you get to choose which side you're on. The object of the game is to fill your play area with all seven VIRTUES or all seven SINS to claim the victory, but watch out: Your opponents will be attempting to do the exact same thing, and will be trying to turn your characters against you!

Features:

 Dual sided cards grant you the flexibility to adjust to an ever changing game state.
 Convert cards to either bring you closer to victory or to disrupt your opponents.
 Fast-paced actions ensures that turns are always quick and exciting.

Poltergeist Heist is a competitive game for 1-5 players that takes 75 minutes to play.

In Poltergeist Heist you must collect clues in order to find the hidden ghosts. Once the ghost is revealed you must act quickly to trap him, otherwise another player may claim the prize.

Airships vs Aliens is a quick strategy boardgame for two players, with one player defending the Earth with ten Steampunk Airship miniatures, while the opposing player attempts to win the invasion using ten alien ship miniatures. The game is pure strategy with no luck elements involved.

Each side has 5 Gunships, 3 Warships and 2 Commandships. The first player to eliminiate both opposing Commandships wins. Each turn a player takes actions with one piece. An action is moving one square forward in the direction facing, turning the ship 90 degrees or firing the long range guns. Gunships have no long range guns, Warships have them with a range of 1 square forward and Commandship long guns can fire with a range of 2 squares forward. Gunships have up to 4 actions when moved, Warships have 3 and Commandships have 2.

To deepen the strategy each side has 5 command tokens that one can be used during a turn to give a ship an extra action. Another strategy element is that when you lose Warships or Commandships you may be able to bring a destroyed ship back to board as reinforcements.

name.value: Bumble Bees: The Nest Building Game

item.description:
In Bumble Bees: The Nest Building Game you are the Queen of a Bumble Bee colony racing to expand your Nest in the Spring. The only problem is you're old and dying. Will you be able to grow your Nest soon enough for a New Queen to be born, or will your colony be wiped out first?

Decide which actions to take with four unique, double sided Bees. The Queen, Worker, Nest Worker, and Drone.

Every turn Event cards are drawn that might have minor, or major effects on gameplay.

Turn you Bumble Bee nest into a resource creating factory by expanding it. You can add new chambers such as Brooding Bees, Honeypots, and Involucrum.

Each game decide where you nest came from, by picking an Origin Card, such as Rodent Nest, Hibernation Hole, or Tree Trunk.

A two player abstract game played with two sets (black and white) of triangular pieces on a hexagonal board. The board has 96 triangular shapes in blue, yellow and red. Players alternate playing one piece at a time trying to form complete hexagons of their own colour. Red areas cannot be played on until they become the only exposed area in a hexagon and at that point may only be played on when the play would creat a complete hexagon all of one colour, in which case that player wins.
 Should no complete uni-coloured hexagon be formed when all legal plays have been made there is a point scoring system to determine the winner.

Inspired by Mexican Lucha Libre Wrestling, El Luchador Fantastico Grande challenges you to become either a hero in the ring, or a villain that teams up and then chair shots people to the face!

Inspired by Mexican Lucha Libre Wrestling,El Luchador Fantastico Grande challenges you to become a righteous hero, or vile villain, in the ring. Fight alone, or team up with another player, and then chair shot your team-mate in the face! Do whatever it takes to win the coveted title belt and claim your spot as the greatest Luchador of all time.

El Luchador Fantastico Grande is a standalone card and dice tabletop game that challenges players to become Mexican wrestling super-stars. Players compete to see who can outlast and knock out all opponents or play in one of the three different match modes. Are you ready to become the ultimate Luchador Wrestler?

El Luchador Fantastico Grande is designed for anyone who loves tabletop gaming, no requirement to know ANYTHING about wrestling.

At the start of each turn, you roll four dice. The dice show the following three symbols: Heal, Miss and Attack. Over three successive throws, choose whether to keep or discard each die in order to restore health, or attack other players.

The strongest wrestler will control the ELFG Title Belt, and be able to deal additional damage, but that player can't heal!

Top this off with a special communal card deck that allows players to deal extra damage, heal, change die results and even counter other players cards!

In order to win the game, one must be the only surviving wrestler once the fighting has ended.

item.description:
As a medieval ruler your aim is to develop crafts, build efficient production chains, and make your city thrive. Produce, transform, gather resources, and don't forget to hinder your opponents!

Artificium is a card-driven development game. Some cards produce resources or transform one type of resources into another and award victory points, while others let you perform actions. Carefully planning the chain of cards that you will play during the game turn is the key to success.

Artificium lasts four turns. At the start of each turn, players have five cards in hand, with six cards being face-up on the table as a card market. During the turn, players first have a chance to exchange some cards from their hands with those in the market, then they play and resolve their cards step by step, performing actions, trading and gathering resources, and most importantly, refining certain resources into other resources to earn victory points. Crystals on the players' individual resource boards keep track of their resources as they are bought and sold. Crystals placed beside the board represent player's coins. The final score is determined after the fourth turn, with players selling any remaining resources to score additional victory points (one point per four coins). The player with the most victory points is considered to be the wisest medieval ruler and is declared the winner.

item.description:
All of the spaces on the game board, feature advertisements of the many stores and businesses in the town of McBain, Michigan. You go around as you would on monopoly and buy, sell and trade property.

This version [2013 Edition] is the first edition of the game, released by the McBain High School, it was released for sporting events and gifted to the 2013 graduating class.

Spyfall is a party game unlike any other, one in which you get to be a spy and try to understand what's going on around you. It's really simple!

Spyfall is played over several rounds, and at the start of each round all players receive cards showing the same location — a casino, a traveling circus, a pirate ship, or even a space station — except that one player receives a card that says "Spy" instead of the location. Players then start asking each other questions — "Why are you dressed so strangely?" or "When was the last time we got a payday?" or anything else you can come up with — trying to guess who among them is the spy. The spy doesn't know where he is, so he has to listen carefully. When it's his time to answer, he'd better create a good story!

At any time during a round, one player may accuse another of being a spy. If all other players agree with the accusation, the round ends and the accused player has to reveal his identity. If the spy is uncovered, all other players score points. However, the spy can himself end a round by announcing that he understands what the secret location is; if his guess is correct, only the spy scores points.

After a few rounds of guessing, suspicion and bluffing, the game ends and whoever has scored the most points is victorious!

item.description:
You are invited to an exciting railway journey in Europe – from Moscow to Paris, from Rome to Berlin. Build your own routes, play wagon cards and watch your opponents!

Moscow to Paris is a quick and easy card game. Four city cards are revealed and placed for all to see. Then players try to match wagon cards played besides cities to wagon cards that they play in their own areas. There are also special cards and cities that bend the rules. You can even add your own city to the game!

A traveler that visited the most cities will win the game!

item.description:
Meazy N More! is essentially a game system, comprising 144 dice — 36 for each player, 6 each in 6 colors. You can play with two copies of the game to allow 5–8 players. An unusual feature of this game system is that there are core rules that all the games use. The core rules instruct players to roll their dice, form legal combinations for the game they're playing, then put their unused dice back in their "rolling bins", and pass them to the left. Each such round of veritable drafting is called a "shake". Shakes continue until someone wins the game.

Meazy N More! comes with rules for four games built upon those core rules:

 In Eazy Meazy (30 minutes, ages 5+), you must build a "pyramid" of dice: 1×1 though 6×6; however, each "level" of one number must be a different color, and once a die is assigned to a level, that level's color is locked.
 Not So Eazy Meazy (30 minutes, ages 5+) differs from Eazy Meazy by allowing the player to choose on the fly which number goes in each level; rearranging is completely legal.
 Meazy Street (90 minutes, ages 8+) is the featured game (ages 8+). In addition to forming a pyramid, you must form a "straight" and a "rainbow", but these things must be done in a particular sequence. Unlike the previous two games, you calculate your score for the round based on the combinations you form.
 Splitting Headache (90 minutes, ages 8+) is billed as a bonus game. In this game, you try to form the four different types of "splits", after which you may work to form the "banana split" out of the remaining dice. You calculate your score for the round based on the splits you formed by the time the round ended.




Further games for the system will be released as expansion packs and/or downloads from the publisher's website.

Road to Heaven Board Game is a fun multi-sensory game created to bring families together & bring the Bible alive in the hearts of all ages and backgrounds thereby drawing them to God and on their own Road to Heaven. The Road to Heaven was developed to provide people of all ages and backgrounds the opportunity to experience and learn the Word of God as spoken through our Lord Jesus Christ and as written in the Bible while having fun through an interactive multi-sensory game.

Travel 157 spaces from worldliness all the way through the cross and end at Heaven’s Gates. But beware. Do you have what you need to get into Heaven? Along the streets paved with gold, players will learn how to live a true Christian life. Players will need to think strategically as they meet up with temptations and worldliness, a simple roll of the dice can determine your fate. Will you roll one die or two? Which piece or card will you decide to take? Encounter the forgiveness of the Lord and rejoice will the blessings showered upon you. The Holy Spirit is your guide, helper and companion throughout the game. As you play you will: Experience excitement to draw your family and friends together; Progress along the books of the Bible; Draw cards to test your Bible knowledge; Be reminded of strategies for addressing temptations in your life; Learn the difference between the wisdom of God and the foolishness of the world
Realize the importance of having the Holy Spirit as your companion and helper.

The Road to Heaven Board Game design and game pieces are biblically based and include 3 sets of playing cards (Bible Book Cards, Blessing Cards and Knowledge Cards) and the following CUSTOM plastic pieces: 13 Lambs Book of Life pieces, 6 Crosses, 7 Earths, 6 Earth Stands, 6 Tips and Reminder Cards and 12 playing tokens in the shape of the Ichthys symbol or "Jesus fish" which are typically used to proclaim an affiliation with or affinity for Christianity.

Road to Heaven Board Game comes with a full size bible and has original art work. Both the cards and plastic pieces are made of higher quality than is required and standard. A minimum price of $39.95 plus tax per game was suggested by the manufacturer (plus shipping). It is priced to sell.

Road to Heaven Board Game is a fun, family-oriented, Bible focused board game designed to be as competitive and engaging as it is spiritually enriching. It is a game that will bring families together while at the same time teach all ages the books of the Bible and the scripture inside. You learn about the Bible in the midst of the ups and downs of the action.There is nothing comparable on the market that can provide a platform to learn the Bible in such a fun and exciting way! What an opportunity to outreach and introduce Jesus to unbelievers in a non-threatening way. You never know what will happen next. We pray and know that this game will have a positive impact on your life and that you have a great time playing it again and again.

Road to Heaven is a wholesome Christian game that’s fun AND meaningful. Road to Heaven teaches you how to live your life for Christ. Learn how even good things come out of bad things that happen along the Road to Heaven. This teaches that challenges you go through become opportunities for you to help others grow.

DESCRIPTION: Darkrock Ventures is a worker placement game about mining and exporting in a hostile outer space. Players will be controlling a mining company working in harsh conditions to acquire the most credits.

GENERAL INFO: A euro game for 1-5 players that plays in about 30-45 minutes.

THEME: Science Fiction. Space is a hostile environment with a known alien presence. Resources are scarce and it is commonplace for companies to mine asteroids to acquire them. It is known that aliens raid these asteroids and therefore mining companies are geared accordingly in preparation of being attacked. Lives are lost in this line of work daily, but if you run a good crew you can make it out alive and rich!

HOOK: Richly thematic euro incorporating dice and dice manipulation, with worker placement, resource farming and exporting.

WINNING CONDITION: Highest Credits when the end of the game is triggered. Credits are acquired primarily from exporting minerals mined from the asteroid.

MECHANICS: A round begins with rolling a set of Power Dice, these are community dice that players will use in order to successfully mine the asteroid. Players then take turns placing workers throughout different space stations and on a mineral rich asteroid.

After all the workers have been placed a third and more volatile Power Die is rolled. A player starts his/her turn by rolling his/her Rig Dice, these represent the a power element of his/her mining equipment that is to be paired with the community Power Dice in order to successfully mine resources from the asteroid. Then he/she resolves all his/her workers. As soon as players begin exporting minerals, hostile alien ships begin patrolling and will attack every round making it more difficult to resolve all the workers successfully.

Throughout the game, players will be increasing their worker count, gaining and spending credits (which are the victory points), gaining additional Rig Dice and acquiring explosive Neutronium bombs to protect them from the alien attacks.

When 3 of the 6 resource nodes on the asteroid are void of minerals the end of the game is triggered. The round is finished and the player with the most credits wins the game.

Darkrock Ventures will also include special 2-player game rules, as well as a Solo/Co-Operative variant.

item.description:
You are a farm owner at the end of the XIX Century, but in a pretty weird world, after weird experiments vegetables have come alive and crazy events can make your plan change in a second. Plant crops, buy animals, ghater resources, manufacture products, construct buildings, achieve missions and get those Victroy Points to Win.

There are 5 basic resources (tomato, raspberry, wood, wheat and Corn). You start the game drawing 5 resource cards from the Resource deck, drawing 1 Annual Mission (1 mission/place card and 2 mission/order cards) and drawing 1 Reward Card. Also you place your mini-gameboard in front of you. Resources pay everything, wood for buildings and different costs for Manufacture products and buying/feeding animals.

At the beginning of each season, you fulfill your hand till have 5 cards, but of course this are randomly drawed from Resource deck, and you cannot give it all to random cause you have only 4 season to complete "on time" your mission, and receive the bonus and a Reward card, and there is when Planting crops become important.

At the beginning of each year, each player receives a new annual mission by drawing a mission/place card and 2 mission/order mini-cards. To obtain the bonus specified by the mission/place card as well as a reward, both missions/orders must be completed in time (by the end of the year.).

Each Resource card have the "cost" of planting the crop in the upright corner (i.e Tomato have 2), so to plant, just place a resource card/crop on the table and discard the cards necessary from your hand. ONE token is then placed on the first blank space, in the next turn you place another token or harvest if ready (The crop is ready for harvest on the turn after the last token has been placed). The harvested crops represented by tokens are placed in their corresponding space in the barn, and the card return to your hand.

Each card lists the products that can be manufactured that resource. To manufacture simply pay the cost using either resource cards, and/or resources token stored in the barn, (the cards used go to the discard pile and tokens used are back to the token pile). Then place a token on its corresponding place on the shelve. You may manufacture as many products as desired (or posible) per turn.

There are 2 kinds of buildings in the game. Common buildings (Stables, Dairy, Henhouse, Sheep Yard), each player can build his own. And uniques buildings (Train Station, General Store, Inn, and Workshop).

The game ends after 12 rounds/seasons, after which the player with the highest amount of victory points wins. Victory points obtained during the game (by completing missions) are added to the points given by Resources, products and buildings.

W.W.B Trivia was one of a number of games that was to go in the W.W.B Deluxe Set that never got published. It is a trivia game that added another element to W.W.B. In the game, players would have to answer a trivia question when they landed on a space, before they rolled the die to see if they stayed. If they answered wrong, they failed and went back to start. The trivia questions were basic math problems. Examples of the questions consisted of, when a player landed on the 1 space being asked what 1+0 was, and when landing on the 5 space being asked what 2+3 was.

W.W.B: Deckbuilder was one of a number of games that was to go in the W.W.B Deluxe Set that never got published. It is a deckbuilding cardgame utilizing the cards from W.W.B.

In the game, the cards had different values from $1 to $25 dollars. Players started off with a single hand of 5 $1 cards. During their turn, they could buy one card from the available remaining cards that were left, put it in their discard pile with the cards in their hand and deal 5 more cards, reshuffling when their deck was empty. Play continued until all cards were gone. Player with the most expensive deck at the end of the game won.

name.value: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire (Second Edition)

item.description:
In an almost identical format to its predecessor, players answer multiple-choice trivia questions of increasing difficulty, with the option of quitting with their winnings up to that point. This adaptation has makeshift versions of the TV show's "Ask the Audience" and "Phone a Friend" lifelines. Players rotate as host, and after everyone has taken a turn as host, winnings are totaled.

Based on the original ABC version of the world-famous game show, hosted by Regis Philbin from 1999-2002.

item.description:
Can you escape from the Pirate's Island?
Words are out about the Royal Navy's discovery of the Pirate's Island. Their arrival is imminent in 12 days.
You are pirates and you must organize your escape before the Royal Navy catches up on you!
In order to escape, are you ready to conspire with corsairs in the Island's tavern, acquire the necessary booty from the black market and hire skillful crew?
Don't forget that you have to use your wits and discover areas of the island forgotten by its residents! You may even have to setup an ambush in the island's bridge along with "Goldtooth"...
How far are you willing to go?

GAMEPLAY:
Players alternate turns placing Pirates and Deckhands on locations of the board, that they think will help them advance strategically, taking accordingly, gear, allies, supplies or dubloons. Several locations are available in the beginning of the game, but new locations may be discovered later during the game.
After all players are done placing Pirates and Deckhands on the board, an event card is revealed that may affect players.
When the event is resolved, Pirates and Deckhands are removed from the board and returned next to the player's mats. We've squeezed out of this day as much as we could. Time to rest.

item.description:
In Flanders Field takes the player to the very heart of what it would have been like to be a CO in the trenches of Flanders. At every move you must make decisions that will determine the fate of the men you command. Your troops must face bombardment from the enemy's artillery, tanks and aeroplanes. How many men will you risk on a particular course of action?

A game for 2-4 players where you take a role as a British Company Commander attempting to be the first to reach the "Objective Line". You start from your own trench and must advance across "No Man's Land" while trying to limit your casualties. It's a "push your luck" game where you roll dice and play cards matching the roll, after which you can decide to try to advance further, or stop and carry out card actions. Pushing too far could incur heavy losses.

Players alternate turns placing object cards in a chest, face down. Each player during his/her turn must name all the objects that were placed in the chest from previous turns.

Οι παÎ¯κτες τοποθετοÏν κÎ¬ρτες αντικειμÎ­νων σε Î­να μπαοÏλο κλειστÎ­ς. ΚÎ¬θε παÎ¯κτης στην σειρÎ¬ του πρÎ­πει να πει ÏŒλα τα αντικεÎ¯μενα που Î­χουν Î®δη τοποθετηθεÎ¯ στο μπαοÏλο.

Creatures from outer space have arrived on Earth and they want to communicate with us, but they need to learn our language.

With Sblap, you have to say words so that the aliens can learn to communicate. This game requires speed, a sharp eye, creativity and memory. Is so appropriate to train memory, attention and creativity capacities and also communication and social skills needed in any social context.

1. Deal all the cards among the players more or less evenly. It doesn't matter if a given player receives an extra card.

2. Each player will form a stack of cards in front of him/her. Cards must be placed face down so that no one can see them.

3. The player with the strangest face begins, by taking a card and placing it face up in the middle of the table, within reach of all the players. Clockwise, each player will take a card and place it in the central stack. The moment two cards showing the same alien or the same letter coincide, any player can cover the central stack with his/her hand and the fastest in doing so must shout out a word beginning with the letter on the covered card.

Then, he/she must take all the cards from the central stack and, mockingly, distribute them how he/she chooses among the remaining players. This player will place a new card in the central deck to continue the game. The cards that players receive are incorporated to their stack of cards at the bottom.

4. The game continues in the same way: the moment two aliens or letters coincide again, any player can cover the central stack with his/her hand and, at that moment, he/she must shout out the preceding word and add a new one beginning with the letter on the card that he/she has just been covered.

Progressively, a word sequence will be formed that must be memorized. If a mistake is made while shouting out the word sequence or if a word is invalid because of a spelling mistake or if he/she has covered the central deck when two cards do not match, the player receives the central stack of cards and places a new card in the central deck to continue the game. The existing word sequence is eliminated and begins to reform.

5. The first player to get rid of all of his/her cards wins the game. 
Variations of the game: play using not just real words but also words in other languages, invented words or sounds.

This game allow you to discover the history, traditions and folklore of an italian province, answering to many question regarding 6 big themes (history, curiosity, geography, etc..) and gaining control of areas in the map, scoring points that will lead you to victory.

A correct answer allow you to put a meeple in an area, and to draw a card that can help you during the game. During established turns in the game you will verify who control the areas, and score point accordingly.

There are many version of this game, regarding many province: Bergamo (first version), Brescia, Brianza, Padova, Treviso, Venezia, Verona, Vicenza.

item.description:
I SPY Original is a memory game based on the I Spy line of classic children's books and the photographs of Walter Wick and Jean Marzollo. The catch is that the images aren't exact matches. Instead, one version may be a silhouette or from another angle. According to the instructions, recognizing an object in a different environment is a valuable pre-reading skill.

Several variants are included in I SPY Original.

Cards represent different regions and industries in the U.S. You represent three of them. Two are public for the other players to see, the third, well, that's your hidden agenda! To win, you'll want to satisfy at least two of your three.

Rules are 1 page long. Game takes approximately 60 minutes for a 3-6 player game, and 30 minutes for two players. Game is downloadable as a print and play from the official website.

item.description: In Vikings: The Card Game, 2-4 players compete to gain 'Renown' to win the game as the most famous Viking of their time. Players may earn 'renown' by exploring, raiding, and settling new lands. Players win the new lands by bidding the number of fleets they will commit to the adventure, then comparing strength totals of the fleets committed.

Since Pinocchio has come to the Carpenter's house, the Carpenter is no longer lonely. However, because naughty Pinocchio lies too often, he gradually fails to distinguish between true and false. Therefore, one day, the Angel told Pinocchio: "If you can finish an adventure on your own without telling any lies and detect the lies of the others in the journey, you will become a 'real' boy." Can Pinocchio eventually become a real boy and live happily ever after with the Carpenter?

Pinocchio: True or False is an enlightening and bonding storytelling game. A player draws a subject card, chooses one of the four subjects on the card, decides whether the story she is going to tell will be true or just a lie, then begins her story. The other players listen to the story to judge its veracity. After the story has been told, the one who grabs the Pinocchio doll first can ask the storyteller a question, which the storyteller must answer honestly — unless her story is a lie, of course, in which case she can say what she wants.

Each player then secretly votes on whether or not the story was a lie. Those who guess incorrectly must take a wooden nose block and make Pinocchio's nose grow by stacking their block onto his ever-lengthening nose. When a player places the nose block, the tree rings on the block must be fully covered and not visible. If any blocks fall, whoever caused this gets an "Angel Token". When a player gets his third angel token, the game ends after this round, and the player with the fewest angel tokens win.

In order to make gameplay more challenging, if half or more players guess correctly as to whether the story is or isn't true, the storyteller must also add a block to the nose. Therefore, the storyteller should do her best to make the story confusing.
